docTitle.titlePart:
Session Title:
Agents Causing DNA Damage or Proteasome Inhibition
Presentation Title:
PM01183 is a novel compound that binds DNA and displays cytotoxic effect in vitro and in
vivo in human cancer cell lines

front.note:

byline.docAuthor:
Victoria Moneo, Juan F. Martínez-Leal, María José Guillén, Patricia Martinez, Guillermo
Tarazona, Pablo M. Aviles, Carmen Cuevas, Luis F. Garcia-Fernandez, Carlos M.
Galmarini.

byline.affiliation: Cell Biology and Pharmacology Departments, PharmaMar, S.A.U.,

front.div:
PM01183 is a novel alkaloid that covalently binds to the minor groove of the DNA. In the present work, we show that
PM01183 displays a potent cytotoxic activity on a panel of 23 human tumor cell lines, with a mean GI 50 value of 10
nM. To determine whether p53 tumor suppressor gene has any effect on PM01183 cytotoxicity we clustered the
panel cell lines into two groups depending on their p53 status: wild-type p53 (n=8) and mutant or null p53 (n=14),
according to the information contained in the Sanger Database. Mean GI 50 for wild-type p53 cell lines was 19 nM;
mean GI 50 for mutant or null p53 cell lines was 4.7 nM. The difference in GI 50 between both groups was statistically
significant (p=0.026; one-tailed Student's t unpaired test). We also show that PM01183 binds in vitro to naked DNA
through band-shift experiments. Furthermore, PM01183-DNA adducts eventually give rise in vivo to double strand
breaks, which we followed through the accumulation of g-H2AX foci as a surrogate indicator. With a sensitive ELISA
assay we verified that PM01183-induced DNA damage triggered caspase-dependent apoptotic cell death, most
probably due to the early DNA damage response caused by the drug. In vivo tumor profiling of compound PM01183
was accomplished by using a panel of six human tumor types, i.e., breast (MDA-MB-231 and MX-1), kidney
(MRI-H-121), ovary (A2780), pancreas (Capan-1) and prostate (PC-3). Briefly, athymic nude mice were
subcutaneously implanted with either tumor fragment or matrigel-cell suspensions on Day 0. When tumors reached
ca. 175 ± 100 mg, mice were randomly allocated into treatment and control groups (n=10-15 animals/group).
Treatments were initiated (Day 0) and intravenously administered on an individual body weight basis. PM01183 was
weekly administered for 3 consecutive weeks at 0.18 mg/kg/dose. Mean, standard deviation and standard error of
the mean were determined for tumor volume assessments. PM01183 demonstrated statistically significant antitumor
(P<0.05) activity against breast (MDA-MB-231: T/C % = 40 on Day 21; MX-1: T/C % = 0 on Day 34) , kidney
(MRI-H-121: T/C % = 40 on Day 35) and ovary (A2780: T/C % = 34 on Day 17). In pancreas and prostate tumors,
only a trend to significance was observed after PM01183 administration. Taken together, the results presented in this
work support the future development of PM01183 as an anticancer agent in the clinic.
